I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Government of Tuvalu expressed a need for technical assistance (TA) in 2011 to 
support its fiscal stability and capacity-improving initiatives.1 The TA will address priority areas 
of  weaknesses  identified  in  the  public  expenditure  and  financial  accountability  (PEFA) 
assessment and the diagnostic analysis of the Ministry of Finance and Economic Development 
(MFED) report. It will also assist the government implement the Public Enterprise (Accountability 
and Transparency) Act 2009. The TA will also assist the government to achieve some of the 
policy  actions  identified  in  the  government  policy  reform  matrix.  Improving  public  financial 
management  (PFM)  and  public  enterprise  performance  is  a  priority  area  in  the  national 
development strategy (Te Kakeega II)2 and ADB's country partnership strategy.3 
 
2.  A  TA  fact-finding  mission  visited  Tuvalu  on  12–17  April  2012.  It  reached  an 
understanding  in  discussions  with  the  government  and  other  stakeholders  on  the  impact, 
outcome, outputs, implementation arrangements, cost, financing arrangements, and terms of 
reference for consulting services. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.4  
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  Tuvalu relies heavily on its public sector as the driver of growth, however the sector is 
inefficient and unwieldy. Tuvalu is in a unique situation whereby external earnings are twice its 
gross domestic product (GDP), leaving the country open to global forces. Since 2008 Tuvalu 
has experienced a decline in key offshore revenues because (i) earnings from fish licenses 
have declined significantly due to low catch in its exclusive economic zone as a result of climatic 
conditions, (ii) the returns on its “.tv” domain name have fallen, and (iii) returns from the Tuvalu 
Trust Fund (TTF) have fallen below their targeted level. More recently, the value of external 
earnings denominated in United States dollars have declined significantly because of exchange 
rate movements.  
 
4.  Total revenues and grants for 2011 were slightly below budget but about 20% higher 
than in 2010. The increase was mainly due to grants. Government expenditure fell by more than 
7% as subsidies were reduced and spending on capital projects declined. These developments 
led to a reduction in the fiscal deficit from more than 30% of GDP in 2010 to about 8% in 2011. 
The market value of the TTF was A$115.1 million at 30 September 2011. This was 9.7% below 
its prescribed maintained value and, as such, no funds were distributed from the TTF into the 
Consolidated Investment Fund (CIF)—the vehicle through which budget deficits are financed. 
The CIF held A$3.1 million in December 2011 and, given the expected deficit, is likely to be 
exhausted in 2012. Further distribution from TTF earnings is not expected until 2014.  Total 
government debt was estimated at 44.3% of GDP in 2010, and may be higher with the status of 
contingent liabilities from joint-venture fishing companies to be determined. Tuvalu is now facing 
unsustainable fiscal pressures. 
 
5.  The government owns eight public enterprises, which operate in key sectors of the 
economy.5 In 2008, with ADB technical assistance (TA),6 the government put in place the Public

Enterprise (Accountability and Transparency) Act 2009. The act provides overarching legislation 
that specifies both the requirements of public enterprises and government responsibilities in 
relation to public enterprises. Prior to this, each public enterprise was governed by its own 
individual act of incorporation. In line with the Public Enterprise Act, the Public Enterprise 
Reform  and  Monitoring  Unit  (PERMU)  was  formed,  and  was  empowered  to  monitor  the 
performance of all public enterprises on behalf of the shareholding ministers, and to advise 
these ministers in respect of the government’s investment in public enterprises. This provides a 
coordinated approach to monitoring public enterprise performance. One of the achievements of 
the  act  is  the  legislating  of  community  service  obligations  (CSOs).  Under  the  act,  the 
government will have to pay CSOs if it wants public enterprises to provide a service to the 
community which is not commercially viable.  
 
6.  A diagnostic analysis of the MFED was also made under the TA. The analysis identified 
a number of performance gaps, including (i) a lack of achievable measurable indicators within 
MFED programs; (ii) a lack of clarity of job descriptions; and (iii) a mismatch between expected 
results and resources, restricting the effectiveness of the MFED in executing and monitoring the 
budget  and  resource  allocation.  These  issues  were  clearly  highlighted  in  the  2011  PEFA 
assessment,  where  it  was  noted  that  both  fiscal  discipline  and  the  strategic  allocation  of 
resources had been undermined due to weaknesses in PFM. The PEFA report also pointed out 
that  efficiency  of  service  delivery  is  constrained  by  the  lack  of  a  procurement  regulatory 
framework. 
 
7.  The  Public  Tenders  Board  (PTB)  Regulations  (2008  revised  edition),  made  under 
section 5 of the Public Finance Act, are the only laws governing procurement in Tuvalu. This 
legislation is very brief and does not provide for many of the elements of a rigorous procurement 
system. The regulations establish a PTB comprising five members, whose functions are to put 
to tender building work not undertaken by the Public Works Department7 and any major disposal 
of government property. In relation to building works, the MFED has the power to direct the PTB 
to enter into direct negotiations with a selected contractor for completion of a particular project. 
The regulations do not cover procurement of goods and services and do not provide for either 
the  public  release  of  information  relating  to  procurement  or  a  complaints  review  process. 
Procurement of goods and services is left to individual ministries to handle, and some ministries 
have established their own procedures while others use “established suppliers” that they have 
dealt with on a regular basis. The underlying aim of developing suitable public procurement 
policy procedures and rules is to ensure that the Government of Tuvalu obtains value for money 
from its public procurement and processes are cost-effective to implement, recognizing that the 
economy is small and there are limited private sector providers.   
 
8.  The Pacific Financial and Technical Assistance Center will assist the government to put 
together  a  PFM  plan,  with  the  Australian  Agency  for  International  Development  (AusAID) 
providing  consultants  to  build  capacity  at  the  auditor  general’s  office  and  the  Treasury 
Department.  In  addition,  development  partners  (ADB,  AusAID,  the  European  Union,  New 
Zealand, and the World Bank) and the government are working on a joint policy reform matrix 
that will identify government priority needs in the medium term, and which will be used to 
coordinate planned budget support.  
                                                                                                                                                          
Bureau, Tuvalu Telecommunication Corporation, and the Vaiaku Lagi Hotel. The Tuvalu Media Corporation has 
been decorporatized. While Parliament has approved the Tuvalu Electricity Corporation (TEC) repeal Act to

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
9.  The intended impact of the TA is improved PFM and public enterprise performance, as 
prioritized in Te Kakeega II. The impact will be monitored through demonstrated improvements 
in the 2014 country performance assessment on the ratings for macroeconomic management 
and fiscal policy. The expected outcome is improved internal corporate planning processes in 
the MFED and strengthened public enterprise oversight. Achievement of the expected outcome 
will be reflected in the government’s capacity to achieve the policy changes it has committed to 
in the joint policy reform matrix.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
10.  The TA will directly respond to the government’s strategic area of good governance 
identified in Te Kakeega II where it gives priority to (i) strengthening public administration 
oversight; (ii) institutionalizing sound management, principles, and practices in the public service; 
and (iii) reducing subsidies to public enterprises through improved management, operations, 
and business planning.8 ADB’s country partnership strategy (footnote 3) also focuses on these 
areas, as poor expenditure allocation decisions have significant opportunity costs that impede 
development and growth in a micro-economy such as Tuvalu.  
 
11.  Output  1:  Improved  human  resource  reform  in  the  Ministry  of  Finance  and 
Economic Development. Under the TA, the findings of the diagnostic analysis and the PEFA 
assessment will be reviewed to determine the steps the government has taken to reduce or 
eliminate the performance gaps identified. Building on this review, the TA consultants will work 
closely with MFED headquarters to develop an appropriate corporate plan for the MFED that will 
provide direction and guidance to all MFED departments and, among other things, (i) establish 
specific, measurable, and achievable key performance targets and outputs with appropriate 
indicators; (ii) improve budget credibility; and (iii) improve budget monitoring and resource 
allocation. The MFED’s corporate plan will form the basis for the formulation of its departmental 
corporate plans. In putting together the MFED's corporate plan, the consultants will consider the 
PFM plan and Te Kakeega II priorities. The TA consultants will also review and update the 
MFED’s job descriptions and establish a simple performance assessment system. 
 
12.  Output  2:  Capacity  development  plan  for  the  Public  Enterprise  Reform  and 
Monitoring Unit fully implemented. The TA will also review the implementation of the Public 
Enterprise  Act  to  identify  areas  that  require  strengthening.  Based  on  this  review,  the  TA 
consultants will develop a capacity building strategy to build the PERMU's understanding of its 
role under the Public Enterprise Act. In developing the strategy, the TA consultants will consider 
CSO  calculations  and  negotiations,  financial  reporting  requirements,  and  public  enterprise 
corporate planning for directors of the PERMU and public enterprises. 
 
13.  Output 3: Procurement policy approved by cabinet. The TA consultants will review 
existing government rules and practices for procurement of goods, works, and services by the 
public sector and build into the PTB Regulations (2008 revised edition) a set of procedures for 
this. The set of procedures should (i) ensure that open competitive procurement is the default 
method of procurement, but define clearly the situations in which other methods may be used 
                                                 
8  This is particularly crucial and rather difficult to implement in a fragile situation such as exists in Tuvalu.

4 
 
and how this is to be justified; (ii) provide for public access to all government procurement plans, 
bidding opportunities, and contract awards; and (iii) provide for an independent administrative 
procurement review process for handling complaints by participants prior to contract signing and 
ensuring that those making procurement decisions are accountable for them. The consultants 
will also identify the merits of various options, including the engagement of an independent third 
party to manage government procurement and having a central procurement unit for a small 
administration such as Tuvalu. 
 
14.  Given the high budget expenditures from previous years and the financial difficulty the 
government is facing, the TA is being formulated on the assumption that the government will 
continue to commit to strengthening PFM and public enterprise performance, as stated in Te 
Kakeega II. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
15.  The TA is estimated to cost $380,400, of which $80,400 will be financed on a grant basis 
by the Government of Australia and administered by ADB, and $300,000 will be financed on a 
grant  basis  by  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Special  Fund  (TASF-IV).  The  government  will 
provide support in kind in the form of counterpart staff, office accommodation, communication 
facilities for consultants, and other in-kind contributions. The cost estimates and financing plan 
are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
16.  The MFED will be the executing agency, and will appoint a TA focal point who will 
oversee the activities of, and maintain information exchange with, the consultant team. The 
consultants will, with the TA focal point, also liaise with development partners to promote 
coordination and complementarity in program and/or project activities. To promote sustainability 
and broad-based commitment to the direction of reforms and guide TA implementation, the TA 
will make use of the steering committee formed under ADB’s TA on Capacity Development for 
Public Financial Management (footnote 6) comprising officials from the MFED, line ministries, 
and representatives from nongovernment organizations and the private sector and chaired by 
the secretary of finance. 
17.  The TA will be implemented over a 12-month period from 1 August 2012 to 30 July 2013 
and will finance 12.5 person-months of intermittent international consulting services and 5 
person-months of national consulting services. The international consultant’s team will comprise 
(i)  a  team  leader  and  strategic  planning  and  human  resource  management  specialist 
(international, 6 person-months); (ii) a public enterprise specialist (international, 3.5 person-
months); and (iii) a procurement specialist (international, 3 person-months). These specialists 
will be joined by a local project facilitation specialist (national, 5 person-months intermittent). 
The consultants will be selected and engaged on an individual basis and according to ADB 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). The proceeds of 
the TA will be disbursed in accordance with the Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook 
(2010, as amended from time to time).

5 
 
18.  The team leader will produce a concise inception report outlining the work program and 
milestones for the duration of the TA, and a final report summarizing the achievements, issues, 
lessons learned, and next steps. Throughout the TA, the team leader will submit (by email) brief 
monthly progress reports summarizing TA activities, progress, issues, and constraints. Team 
members will produce reports on their respective activities for the team leader's progress and 
final reports. The team leader's final report will be submitted in draft form at least 5 weeks prior 
to the end of the assignment, and the final report within 2 weeks of receipt of comments by the 
government and ADB. 
 
19.  Progress of the TA will be monitored using intended outcomes and outputs described in 
the design and monitoring framework (Appendix 1). ADB will assist the government in sharing 
all reports with other development partners. These will be disseminated through meetings, radio 
interviews, and the ADB website. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
20.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved (i) ADB 
administering a portion of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $80,400 to be 
financed on a grant basis by the Government of Australia, and (ii) ADB providing the balance 
not exceeding the equivalent of $300,000 on a grant basis to the Government of Tuvalu for 
Institutional Strengthening of the Ministry of Finance and Economic Development, and hereby 
reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  Consultant services will support this technical assistance (TA). A team leader, who will 
also be a strategic planning and human resources management specialist, will be in charge of 
supervising all consultants and lead the work of the TA. It is expected that the consultants will 
work closely to keep the implementation of the TA on track and in line with its scope and 
objectives. 
 
2.  The TA will be implemented intermittently by a team of three international consultants for 
a  total  of  12.5  person-months  and  one  national  consultant  for  5  person-months.  The 
international consultant’s team will comprise a team leader and strategic planning and human 
resources management specialist (international, 6 person-months); a public enterprise specialist 
(international,  3.5  person-months);  and  a  procurement  specialist  (international,  3  person-
months). These specialists will be joined by a local project facilitation specialist (national, 5 
person-months intermittent). 
 
1.  Team Leader and Strategic Planning and Human Resources Management 
Specialist (international, 6 person-months) 
 
3.  The specialist must have the appropriate background to undertake the task as outlined in 
para. 5 but should in addition be able to act as an efficient and effective agent of change. This 
person  must  also  possess  excellent  capacity  development  and  workshop  preparation  and 
delivery skills, as well as coaching and mentoring skills, to help the Ministry of Finance and 
Economic Planning (MFED) implement the tasks described in paras. 4 and 5. She or he must 
have a broad human resources background and understanding of how to link strategic planning 
and human resources management. She or he must have extensive international experience, 
particularly in the Pacific region, and be adept at applying lessons in reforms in fragile island 
micro-states. 
 
4.  The specialist will take the lead in reviewing the final report of the participatory diagnostic 
analysis of the MFED and the public expenditure and financial accountability assessment. The 
review  shall  determine  if  the  government  has  taken  any  steps  to  reduce  or  eliminate  the 
performance gaps identified in the final report. Building upon this review, the specialist will 
develop  an  appropriate  institutional  operating  strategy  for  the  MFED  that  will  (i)  establish 
achievable and measurable key performance targets and outputs with appropriate indicators, (ii) 
ensure  there  is  proportionality  between  expected  results  and  available  resources,  and  (iii) 
improve budget credibility and resource allocation. 
 
5.  To accomplish this, the specialist will undertake the following tasks: 
(i)  assist the MFED to identify its main institutional and sector strategy objectives 
and link the objectives to relevant components of the MFED 2012 and 2013 
program  budget  descriptions  and  government's  sustainable  development 
strategy (Te Kakeega II); 
(ii)  facilitate the preparation of the MFED’s 3-year rolling strategic plan with activities 
costed for the first year of the plan (2012) and activity costings projected for 2013 
and 2014; 
(iii)  develop and agree upon an annual report format with the MFED and conduct 
workshops that explain how the annual report will describe why the MFED did or 
did not meet its key performance targets;  
(iv)  develop a job description format and use the format to prepare updated job 
descriptions for all MFED staff; the job description format will include information

2.  Public Enterprise Specialist (international, 3.5 person-months)  
 
6.  The specialist is required to have a minimum of 10 years of work experience in areas 
related to the management of privatization processes and the accounting and controlling of 
public enterprises. The specialist must have experience in working with and guiding teams and 
in capacity building, and have good communication skills. Work experience in small Pacific 
island countries is highly desirable. The consultant will undertake the following specific tasks:  
(i)  review  the  implementation  of  the  Public  Enterprise  Act  2009  and,  in  close 
consultation with the Public Enterprise Reform and Monitoring Unit (PERMU), 
develop a capacity building strategy; 
(ii)  provide input as required to support the continued development of the public 
enterprise  performance  monitoring  mechanisms  and  assist  the  PERMU  to 
strengthen  its  monitoring  capacity  through  timely  and  effective  reviews  of 
corporate plans, quarterly reports, and annual reports; 
(iii)  extend particular efforts toward building the capacity of the PERMU in relation to 
all activities under this TA project; 
(iv)  work  closely  with  the  strategic  planning  and  human  resources  management 
specialist  on  understanding  the  capacity  implications  of  the  TA  inputs  and 
propose a short- to medium-term approach for sustainable capacity development 
in public enterprise reform;  
(v)  coordinate  with  development  partner(s)  and  specialists  providing  related 
assistance; and 
(vi)  support the strategic planning and human resources management specialist and 
local project facilitation specialist in the conduct of a public awareness campaign, 
public consultation, and information dissemination on key aspects of the TA work. 
 
3.   Procurement Specialist (international, 3 person-months) 
 
7.  The procurement specialist will have sound practical knowledge of procurement, ideally 
in  the  smaller  Pacific  islands  context.  The  specialist  will  hold  a  recognized  and  relevant 
professional qualification, preferably in law, with extensive international experience in public 
sector procurement of goods, works, and services in small-island countries such as Tuvalu. The 
specialist  should  also  demonstrate  adequate  experience  in  conducting  seminars  and/or 
trainings.

Appendix 3  11 
 
8.  The  specialist  will  analyze  the  existing  procedures  and  practices  in  Tuvalu  and 
recommend appropriate procurement policy. The underlying aim of developing suitable public 
procurement policy procedures and rules is to ensure that the Government of Tuvalu obtains 
value  for  money  from  its  public  procurement.  The  aim  is  to  achieve  this  by  creating, 
implementing,  and  enforcing  suitable  procurement  rules  that  provide  for  contestable 
procurement wherever feasible, accountability for procurement decisions, independent dispute 
resolution procedures, and a procurement system with integrity that encourages bona fide 
suppliers to participate in it. Specific tasks will include the following: 
(i)  review existing government rules and practices for procurement of goods, works, 
and  services  by  the  public  sector,  including  those  involving  bilateral  and 
multilateral cooperation;  
(ii)  make recommendations on the appropriateness of various options including the 
engagement of an independent third party to manage government procurement 
or having a central procurement unit for a small administration such as Tuvalu; 
(iii)  develop a set of feasible procedures (for incorporating into the Public Tenders 
Board Regulations [2008 revised edition]) suitable for the procurement of goods, 
works, and services by the public sector in Tuvalu, i.e., commensurate with the 
scale of procurement and its capacity constraints; the set of procedures should 
(a)  ensure  that  open  competitive  procurement  is  the  default  method  of 
procurement, but define clearly the situations in which other methods may be 
used  and  how  this  is  to  be  justified;  (b)  provide  for  public  access  to  all 
government procurement plans, bidding opportunities, and contract awards; (c) 
provide  for  an  independent  administrative  procurement  review  process  for 
handling complaints by participants prior to contract signing and ensuring that 
those making procurement decisions are accountable for them; 
(iv)  prepare model bidding documents for the procurement of goods, services, and 
civil works by local competitive bidding, and standard bid evaluation reports and 
contract documents for the procurement of goods, civil works, and consultant 
services pursuant to the procurement policy; and 
(v)  prepare  training  materials  and  conduct  seminars  for  staff  of  government 
ministries  and  agencies  that  are  involved  in  managing  or  overseeing 
procurement processes; the training should cover the proposed procurement 
rules, their underlying policy rationale, and typical procurement policy issues that 
may arise and how to deal with them.   
 
4.   Project Facilitator (national, 5 person-months). 
 
9.  The  project  facilitator  will  have  a  strong  background  in  training,  education,  and 
participatory processes. He or she will have extensive experience in technical assistance in 
those fields in small-island states. Under the guidance of the team leader or advisors, the 
project facilitator will undertake the following tasks: 
(i)  prepare  and  facilitate  a  series  of  participatory  public  workshops  to  develop 
awareness  and  understanding  of  the  implications  of  public  enterprise 
performance  and  reforms,  and  undertake  similar  outreach  among 
parliamentarians and relevant government and public enterprise staff; 
(ii)  facilitate trainings in financial management for public enterprise staff and board 
members to develop their ability to understand and perform the financial tasks in 
keeping with their roles; and 
(iii)  reach out to the public through appropriate media on issues within the scope of 
the TA as identified by the team leader and/or advisor.
